claim_summary: At a red light, when are you permitted to turn right in Texas? → After coming to a complete stop and yielding to traffic and pedestrians, unless a sign prohibits it

claim_summary: You are at a red light in the left lane. Can you turn left onto a one-way street in Texas? → Yes, but only from a one-way street onto another one-way street
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What should you do if you are already in an intersection when the light turns yellow? → Continue through the intersection safely
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At a red light, you want to turn right, but a pedestrian is crossing the street you're turning onto. What must you do? → Wait for the pedestrian to completely cross before turning

claim_summary: What is the primary purpose of a yellow traffic light? → To warn that the light is about to turn red

claim_summary: If a traffic signal displays both red and yellow lights at the same time, what does this indicate? → The signal is malfunctioning; treat it as a stop sign

claim_summary: When approaching a green light, why should you still scan the intersection before entering? → Other drivers may run their red light or pedestrians may be crossing
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You arrive at a red light behind several cars. When the light turns green, when should you proceed? → When the vehicle ahead of you has moved and it's safe to proceed
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: Can you enter an intersection on a green light if traffic ahead is backed up and you cannot completely clear the intersection? → No, you must wait until you can completely clear the intersection

claim_summary: What does a solid red traffic signal mean for pedestrians? → Do not begin crossing; wait for the walk signal

claim_summary: What should you do if a traffic signal's green light has been on for a while as you approach? → Be prepared to stop as the light may change soon
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At a red light, where must you stop your vehicle? → At the stop line or before entering the crosswalk
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: If you accidentally run a red light and are already in the intersection, what should you do? → Continue through the intersection quickly and safely
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You are approaching a green light but notice the crosswalk is full of pedestrians still crossing. What should you do? → Wait for all pedestrians to clear the crosswalk before proceeding

claim_summary: What is the minimum duration you should expect for a yellow light at a typical intersection? → 3 to 6 seconds depending on the speed limit

claim_summary: You stop at a red light on a steep downhill grade. When the light turns green, the vehicle ahead of you starts to roll backward. What should you do? → Stay back and honk your horn to alert the driver
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a green arrow signal mean? → You may proceed in the direction of the arrow without yielding
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You see a green left arrow along with a red circular signal. What should you do? → You may turn left only; straight and right movements are prohibited
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a yellow arrow signal indicate? → The protected turn is ending; prepare to stop or yield
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a red arrow signal mean? → You must stop and cannot proceed in the direction of the arrow
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You are in a left turn lane with a green circular signal but no green arrow. What must you do? → Yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians before turning
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At an intersection, you have a green arrow to turn left. Oncoming traffic has what signal? → A red signal preventing them from entering the intersection
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: The signal changes from a green arrow to a green circular signal while you're waiting to turn left. What has changed? → You must now yield to oncoming traffic when turning
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: Can you make a right turn when you see a red arrow pointing right? → No, you must wait for a green signal or arrow
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You are turning left on a green arrow. A pedestrian enters the crosswalk against their signal. What should you do? → Stop and yield to the pedestrian even though you have the right of way
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What is the difference between a green arrow and a green circular signal for turning? → A green arrow is protected; a green circular signal requires yielding to oncoming traffic
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You have a green left arrow. Halfway through your turn, the arrow turns yellow. What should you do? → Complete your turn safely and clear the intersection
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At a complex intersection, you see a green circular signal and a separate red arrow pointing left. What can you do? → Go straight or turn right, but not left
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You are waiting to turn left on a green circular signal. Oncoming traffic is heavy. The light turns yellow. What should you do? → Complete your turn when oncoming traffic stops for their yellow light
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: When turning right on a green circular signal, what must you watch for? → Pedestrians crossing and vehicles turning left from the opposite direction
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does it mean if you see a green right arrow? → You have a protected right turn with no conflicting traffic
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: While waiting to turn left with a green circular signal, you should position your vehicle how? → In the intersection with wheels straight, not turned

claim_summary: A traffic signal shows a yellow arrow for your left turn, but you haven't entered the intersection yet. What should you do? → Stop if you can do so safely; the protected turn is ending

claim_summary: When you see a green arrow pointing left, which direction should you turn? → Left

claim_summary: What does a flashing red traffic signal mean? → Stop, then proceed when safe, treating it like a stop sign
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a flashing yellow traffic signal mean? → Slow down and proceed with caution
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You approach an intersection with a flashing red signal while cross traffic has a flashing yellow signal. What should you do? → Stop completely, then proceed when safe after yielding to cross traffic
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: When are you most likely to encounter flashing traffic signals? → Late at night or during low traffic periods, or when signals are malfunctioning
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At an intersection, you have a flashing yellow signal. What right of way do you have? → Proceed with caution but yield to any vehicles already in the intersection
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: If all signals at an intersection are flashing red in all directions, how should you proceed? → Treat the intersection as a four-way stop
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You approach an intersection where the signal is completely dark with no lights showing. How should you proceed? → Treat it as a four-way stop and stop before entering
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What is the key difference between a flashing yellow and a solid yellow signal? → Flashing yellow means proceed with caution; solid yellow means prepare to stop
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At an intersection with a flashing red signal, two vehicles from different directions arrive at exactly the same time. Who has the right of way? → The vehicle on the right
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a steady WALK signal mean for pedestrians? → Begin crossing the street
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a steady DON'T WALK or raised hand signal mean? → Do not start crossing the street
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a flashing DON'T WALK signal mean? → Do not start crossing; finish crossing if already in the street
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: You are a pedestrian and the WALK signal turns to a flashing DON'T WALK when you are halfway across a wide street. What should you do? → Continue crossing to the other side or to a safety island
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What does a pedestrian countdown timer indicate? → The number of seconds remaining to finish crossing before the DON'T WALK phase
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: A pedestrian countdown timer shows 3 seconds remaining as you approach the crosswalk. Should you start crossing? → No, do not start crossing if you cannot make it across safely
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: What should drivers do when they see a pedestrian signal showing WALK for a crosswalk they want to turn through? → Wait for pedestrians to cross; they have the right of way
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: At an intersection with pedestrian signals, you have a green left arrow. What should the pedestrian signal show? → DON'T WALK, preventing pedestrians from crossing into your path
authoritative_source: TX DPS DL-7 handbook / TX Transportation Code

claim_summary: A pedestrian signal shows WALK but the traffic signal for vehicles shows green in the same direction. A driver wants to turn right. Who has the legal right of way? → The pedestrian; drivers must yield
